coredata.dc:title: Hierarchical porous nickel supported NiFeOxHy nanosheets for efficient and robust oxygen evolution electrocatalyst under industrial condition
coredata.dc:creator: Zhong, Bo
Kuang, Panyong
Wang, Linxi
Yu, Jiaguo
coredata.dc:description: As an ideal clean energy carrier, hydrogen is regarded as the most promising alternative to replace fossil fuels in the future energy system. Compared to the traditional steam reforming process, water electrolysis is an innovative method for green hydrogen production. The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) with slow kinetics limits the efficiency of water electrolysis, thus, the fabrication of efficient and robust electrocatalysts for OER is highly desirable to promote the development of hydrogen industry. Herein, we developed a robust OER electrocatalyst by coupling NiFeOxHy nanosheets with porous nickel (PN) substrate via bubble template method. The NiFeOxHy-PN electrocatalyst displays superior electrocatalytic performance, the overpotential for OER at 100 mA cm−2 and 1000 mA cm−2 are 265 mV and 326 mV, respectively. Especially, the NiFeOxHy-PN exhibits better activity and durability than the commercial Raney nickel (RN) in alkaline water electrolysis under industrial conditions, which indicates its potential for industrial application. This work provides an efficient strategy to synthesize advanced electrocatalyst for alkaline water electrolysis.

Industrial condition

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Schematic diagram for the synthesis of NiFeOxHy-PN electrocatalyst.
(a) FESEM image of PN; (b, c) FESEM images of NiFeOxHy-PN; (d) high-resolution TEM image; (e) SAED pattern of NiFeOxHy nanosheet; and (f) the corresponding elemental mapping images of Ni, Fe and O.
(a) XRD pattern of NM, PN and NiFeOxHy-PN; (b) photos of contact angles of PN and NiFeOxHy-PN; high-resolution XPS spectrums of (c) Ni 2p and (d) Fe 2p of NiFeOxHy-PN.
FESEM images of PN with electrodeposition time of (a) 300 s, (b) 600 s, and (c) 900 s; FESEM images of NiFeOxHy-PN with electrodeposition time of (d) 100 s, (e) 200 s, and (f) 300 s.
Electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction. (a) The polarization curves. (b) Tafel plots and (c) EIS curves of NM, PN and NiFeOxHy-PN. (d) Stability test of NiFeOxHy-PN.
The morphology and elemental analysis of NiFeOxHy-PN after the durability test. (a) FESEM image; (b) XRD spectra; XPS spectra of (c) Ni 2p and (d) Fe 2p.

Performance of catalysts under industrial conditions. (a) Polarization curves, (b) the cell voltage at 400 mA cm−2, (c) stability test at 400 mA cm−2 for 12 h, (d) the cell voltage changes of RN and NiFeOxHy-PN.
OER performance of different electrocatalysts in 1 M KOH with the current density of 100 mA cm−2.

head.ce:title: Hierarchical porous nickel supported NiFeOxHy nanosheets for efficient and robust oxygen evolution electrocatalyst under industrial condition

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: As an ideal clean energy carrier, hydrogen is regarded as the most promising alternative to replace fossil fuels in the future energy system. Compared to the traditional steam reforming process, water electrolysis is an innovative method for green hydrogen production. The oxygen evolution reaction (OER) with slow kinetics limits the efficiency of water electrolysis, thus, the fabrication of efficient and robust electrocatalysts for OER is highly desirable to promote the development of hydrogen industry. Herein, we developed a robust OER electrocatalyst by coupling NiFeOxHy nanosheets with porous nickel (PN) substrate via bubble template method. The NiFeOxHy-PN electrocatalyst displays superior electrocatalytic performance, the overpotential for OER at 100 mA cm−2 and 1000 mA cm−2 are 265 mV and 326 mV, respectively. Especially, the NiFeOxHy-PN exhibits better activity and durability than the commercial Raney nickel (RN) in alkaline water electrolysis under industrial conditions, which indicates its potential for industrial application. This work provides an efficient strategy to synthesize advanced electrocatalyst for alkaline water electrolysis.

ce:section.ce:para: Hydrogen is an ideal energy carrier for the sustainable energy system, due to its high gravimetric energy density and friendliness to the environment [1–8]. At present, the main strategy to produce hydrogen is steam reforming of methane, which extremely relies on non-renewable fossil fuels [9]. It is urgent to develop sustainable technologies for hydrogen production to meet the growing energy demands [10–12]. Water electrolysis is a promising approach to store intermittent renewable energy through the conversion of electricity into stable hydrogen energy [13–20]. Though water electrolysis is a mature and efficient technology for hydrogen production, the cost of hydrogen is still expensive because of the large amount of electricity consumption [21]. Due to the large overpotential and sluggish kinetics, the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) severely limits the efficiency of water electrolysis [22–27]. Thus, designing of efficient and robust OER electrocatalyst is vital for the development of water electrolysis.

From the perspective of industrial-scale alkaline water electrolysis, an ideal electrode should meet strict criteria, including mechanical robustness under corrosive environment, long-term electrochemical durability at high current density, and stable load under continuous gas evolution [28,29]. Currently, Raney nickel (RN) mesh is the common commercial electrocatalyst for industrial alkaline water electrolysis. Nevertheless, the electrocatalytic performance of RN is unsatisfied, which resulted from the complex synthesis process, unstable electrocatalyst loading and poor electrocatalytic activity. Besides, bubbles generated by gas evolution tend to cover electrode surface and block access of electrolytes to reactive sites, further increasing the overpotential [30–32]. To this end, a three-dimensional porous nickel (PN) structure can be achieved by the dynamic bubble template method, employing hydrogen bubbles as a template [33,34]. The hierarchical structure benefits the diffusion of electrolytes as well as the release of bubbles, which avoids the blocking of electrode surface and decreases the excess bubble-evolution-derived overpotential [35].

Apart from gas management, the critical factor for electrocatalytic performance is the intrinsic reactive activity of electrocatalyst. NiFe hydroxide (NiFeOxHy) is regarded as the best non-noble-metal based OER electrocatalyst in alkaline water electrolysis, due to the extraordinary inherent electrocatalytic activity and excellent durability [36–38]. To further improve the catalytic activity of low conductive NiFeOxHy, integrating the NiFeOxHy nanosheets with conductive substrate has been widely investigated [29]. Utilizing insulating polymeric binder is a common method to fabricate electrodes, but it reduces the active surface area and decreases the electrical conductivity. In addition, the electrocatalyst is not stable on the substrates under intensive gas evolution. Compared with other synthetic strategies, the electrodeposition method can be applied to fabricate robust self-standing electrodes with adjustable composition, and this cost-effective method is suitable for large-scale industrial manufacturing [39,40].

Herein, we developed a facile two-step electrodeposition strategy to fabricate robust self-standing electrodes for OER and alkaline water electrolysis. Firstly, the porous nickel layer was loaded on the nickel mesh (NM) via the dynamic bubble template method. Subsequently, the highly active NiFeOxHy nanosheets were fabricated on the PN substrate via an electrodeposition process. The as-prepared NiFeOxHy-PN electrocatalyst displays excellent electrocatalytic activity and durability for OER with 265 mV overpotential at 100 mA cm−2. Further, utilizing as the anode electrode for alkaline water electrolysis, the NiFeOxHy-PN have better electrocatalytic performance and durability than the commercial RN under industrial condition. These results indicate its potential application in industrial alkaline water electrolysis.

All reagents were of analytical grade and were used without further purification. Nickel(II) chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O), ammonium chloride (NH4Cl), nickel(Ⅱ) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), iron(Ⅱ) sulfate heptahydrate (FeSO4·7H2O), potassium hydroxide (KOH), hydrochloric acid (HCl), acetone and ethanol were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd.

Prior to the synthesis process, the commercial NM was treated in 1 M HCl, ultrapure water and ethanol under ultrasonication for 15 min to remove the impurities and oxide layer on the surface, and subsequently dried in air. The NiFeOxHy-PN electrocatalysts were prepared through a two-step method. For the preparation of PN, the electrodeposition was carried out in a two-electrode electrochemical system, where the working electrode was pre-treated NM and the counter electrode was graphite rod. Moreover, the electrolyte solution consisted of 0.1 M NiCl2·6H2O and 2 M NH4Cl. The PN layer was galvanostatic electrodeposited with a cathodic current density of 1 A cm−2. Then the as-prepared PN was washed with ultrapure water and dried in air at room temperature.

Thereafter, an additional electrodeposition process was applied to prepare NiFeOxHy-PN. The two-electrode system contained PN as the working electrode and graphite rod as the counter electrode. The electrolyte solution contained Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and FeSO4·7H2O where the total concentration of metal ions was fixed at 0.1 M. The Fe2+ was applied in this synthesis based on previously published works [41,42]. To avoid oxidation of Fe2+, the water solvent to prepare the electrolyte solution was purged with nitrogen for 30 min prior to the addition of the metal salts. The galvanostatic electrodeposition with a cathodic current density of 10 mA cm−2 was applied. After the electrodeposition process, the NiFeOxHy-PN was rinsed with ultrapure water, then dried in air at room temperature.

The morphologies of electrocatalysts were observed using JEOL JSM-7500F field-emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM). The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) were carried out on a JEOL JEM-2100F with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV, equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured on a Shimadzu XRD-6100 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on Thermo Fisher Scientific ESCALab 250Xi electron spectrometer equipped with Al Kα X-ray source. Contact angle was measured on the contact angle goniometer (Theta Flex, Biolin Scientific, Finland).

All electrochemical measurements were carried out on CHI 760e electrochemical station (Shanghai Chenhua, China) with a standard three-electrode system in 1 M KOH. The as-prepared electrocatalyst was used as the working electrode directly, the Hg/HgO electrode (1 M KOH) and graphite rod were used as the reference and counter electrode, respectively. The overpotential (η) for OER was calculated by the equation η = E RHE − 1.23 V. Before the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) test, cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurement was performed for 20 cycles at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1. The LSV curves were recorded at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 with 95% iR-compensation. Tafel slopes were calculated based on the LSV curves by plotting η with log j. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was obtained at the open circuit potential with 5 mV amplitude and frequency range from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz. The electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) was evaluated by electrochemical double-layer capacitance (Cdl) measurements. The Cdl values were determined by measuring the CVs in a non-Faradaic region with different scan rates of 20, 40, 60, 80 and 100 mV s−1. By plotting the difference current density (Δj) between anodic and cathodic sweeps at a fixed potential against the scan rate, the slope was twice Cdl. The overall water splitting test were recorded in a two-electrode system, using NiFeOxHy-PN as the anode and RN as the cathode. All potentials reported were calibrated to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) according to the equation
E
RHE
=
E
Hg / HgO
+ 0.098 + 0.059 × pH
, unless otherwise noted.

The NiFeOxHy-PN electrocatalyst was fabricated by a two-step electrodeposition process as shown in Fig. 1. As the commercial NM with a smooth surface has negligible active surface area, it is necessary to increase the roughness to expose more active sites (Fig. S1). Thus, a porous layer on the NM surface was created by electrodeposition of Ni nanoparticles via the bubble template method. In a typical synthesis, ultra-large cathodic current density was applied, and H2 bubbles were in situ generated via hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) on NM. Concurrently, Ni2+ ions migrated to the cathode driven by the applied cathodic current and were reduced to nickel nanoparticles on the NM surface. The dynamic H2 generation combined with Ni electrodeposition led to the formation of a porous deposition layer where the generated H2 bubbles served as a dynamic template [34]. Compared to the pristine NM with a smooth surface, the as-prepared 3D PN electrode consists of small channels for the release of gas bubbles and promotes the diffusion of electrolyte. Following the preparation of PN, the NiFeOxHy nanosheets were electrodeposited on the nickel nanoparticles to prepare the NiFeOxHy-PN. The conjunction of the porous PN substrate with ultrathin NiFeOxHy nanosheets leads to a hierarchical structure for the NiFeOxHy-PN electrocatalyst, which increases the active surface area and facilities the gas diffusion.

The morphologies of PN and NiFeOxHy-PN were investigated by FESEM. Different from the pristine NM, the PN shows a 3D porous structure with large specific surface area, which is optimal for electrodeposition of NiFeOxHy nanosheets ( Fig. 2a). Furthermore, the porous substrate consisted of nickel nanoparticles facilitates the electrolyte diffusion and gas release, leading to the increased active area of electrode and reduced ohmic resistance created by surface bubbles [30]. Fig. 2b shows the hierarchical porous structure of NiFeOxHy-PN, where the PN is uniformly covered by ultrathin NiFeOxHy nanosheets. Fig. 2c displays magnified view of the NiFeOxHy nanosheets attached on PN substrate. The ultrathin structure could accelerate electron transfer and expose more active sites. The NiFeOxHy nanosheets were further investigated by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). As shown in Fig. 2d, the HRTEM image of NiFeOxHy nanosheets demonstrated lattice fringes with distances of 0.271 nm and 0.156 nm, corresponding to (100) and (110) planes of Ni(OH)2, respectively. In addition, the lattice fringe spacing of 0.215 nm was attributed to (210) plane of FeOOH. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern in Fig. 2e is indexed to (100), (110) planes of Ni(OH)2 and (210) plane of FeOOH, consistent with the HRTEM results. Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping images in Fig. 2f display the uniform distribution of Ni, Fe and O elements.

XRD pattern in Fig. 3a shows diffraction peaks at 44.5°, 51.8° and 76.4°, which are correlated to (111), (200) and (220) planes of Ni (JCPDS No. 87-0712), respectively. There are no other observable peaks besides the strong peaks of nickel substrate. The surface wettability of PN and NiFeOxHy-PN were investigated by contact angles test. The surface of NiFeOxHy-PN becomes completely wetted by the water drop within 1 s, while the contact angle is 32° on the surface of PN (Fig. 3b). The super-hydrophilic nature of NiFeOxHy-PN favors the diffusion of electrolyte proximate to its surface and facilitates the release of gas bubbles, promoting the electrocatalytic performance at high current density especially [43]. XPS spectrum of Ni 2p shows two peaks located at ~ 856 eV and ~ 874 eV with satellite peaks, indicating the presence of Ni2+ (Fig. 3c) [29]. In addition, the Fe 2p3/2 and Fe1/2 peaks located at 711.6 eV and 725.5 eV are attributed to Fe3+ (Fig. 3d) [44]. These results are in good agreement with the SAED results of NiFeOxHy-PN, which confirms the presence of Ni(OH)2 and FeOOH.

A series of NiFeOxHy-PN electrocatalysts were prepared by varying the time for electrodeposition to study its effect on the morphology and activity of the samples. The morphologies of as-prepared electrocatalysts with different deposition times are shown in Fig. 4. During the preparation of PN via bubble template method, the density of nickel nanoparticles layer increased with the extension of deposition time. The PN-300 with deposition of 300 s exhibits incompletely covered nickel nanoparticles layer and less active surface area (Fig. 4a). As the deposition time increases, the PN-600 shows fully covered uniform porous nickel deposition layer (Fig. 4b). Nevertheless, the PN-900 with a longer deposition time leads to excessive nickel nanoparticles, blocking the pores of porous layer and decreasing the active sites (Fig. 4c). As shown in Fig. S2, the PN-600 with optimal deposition time exhibits the best OER activity. In addition, the morphologies of NiFeOxHy-PN with different deposition times were investigated and the as-prepared NiFeOxHy-PN electrocatalysts showed apparently different morphologies. The NiFeOxHy-PN-100 with a deposition time of 100 s exhibits partial coverage of NiFeOxHy nanosheets on the nickel nanoparticles (Fig. 4d). The NiFeOxHy-PN-200 displays flower-like morphology, where NiFeOxHy nanosheets are uniformly distributed on the PN (Fig. 4e). Moreover, NiFeOxHy-PN-300 with longer electrodeposition time led to thicker nanosheets (Fig. 4f). The ultrathin nanosheets provide larger active surface area, shorter charge transport distance and thus better OER kinetic performance (Fig. S3). In addition, the relationship between the Ni: Fe ratio in electrolyte and OER activity is investigated, and the Ni0.75Fe0.25OxHy-PN shows the best electrocatalytic activity (Fig. S4). Thus, the optimized NiFeOxHy-PN synthesis process is composed of the PN substrate with electrodeposition time of 600 s and the NiFeOxHy nanosheets with 200 s electrodeposition process, in which the electrolyte consisted of Ni:Fe = 3:1.

The electrochemical performance of NM, PN and NiFeOxHy-PN was measured in a typical three-electrode cell containing 1 M KOH. The polarization curves were performed in backward scan mode to avoid the influence of Ni2+/Ni3+ signal, which often appears in positive scans. Fig. 5a displays the OER performance of the NM, PN, and NiFeOxHy-PN electrocatalysts. ECSA of electrode was estimated by the Cdl, which reflected the exposed active surface area. Due to the hierarchical porous nickel layer, PN has significant larger ECSA than NM and thus shows better OER performance than NM (Fig. S5). To get insight into the effects of substrate, we fabricated the NiFeOxHy-NM and NiFeOxHy-PN electrocatalyst. The larger active surface area of PN provides more active sites for the deposition of NiFeOxHy nanosheets, which excludes the better OER performance of NiFeOxHy-PN than NiFeOxHy-NM (Fig. S6) [45]. Compared to NM and PN, the NiFeOxHy-PN shows a significant enhancement in OER activity. To achieve the current density of 100 mA cm−2, NiFeOxHy-PN exhibits an extremely low overpotential of 265 mV, while NM and PN require 746 mV and 456 mV, respectively. The OER performance of NiFeOxHy-PN is comparable or better than the reported NiFe-based catalyst to date ( Table 1). As illustrated in Fig. 5b, NiFeOxHy-PN possess the lower Tafel slope than the NM and PN, indicating the faster kinetics during the OER process. EIS was employed to reveal the reaction kinetics. The Nyquist plot of NiFeOxHy-PN shows an apparent smaller semicircle radius than NM and PN in the low-frequency region, which reveals the lower charge transfer resistance (Fig. 5c). The electrochemical stability test of NiFeOxHy-PN was investigated at the constant current density of 100, 500 and 1000 mA cm−2, where negligible decay is observed after 12 h (Fig. 5d). After the high-current-density stability test, the OER activity of NiFeOxHy-PN shows slight degradation (Fig. S7).

To examine the change of NiFeOxHy-PN during the durability test, the morphology and elemental analysis were conducted. The FESEM image of NiFeOxHy-PN after durability test exhibits that the hierarchical morphology was maintained ( Fig. 6a). Besides, XRD spectra indicate no significant composition changes in NiFeOxHy-PN after durability test (Fig. 6b). Compared the XPS spectra of NiFeOxHy-PN before and after durability test, the chemical states of Ni and Fe remain the same (Fig. 6c, d). These results indicate that no significant composition changes occurred, confirming the stability of NiFeOxHy-PN during the OER process.

Furthermore, we investigated the performance of NiFeOxHy-PN under industrial conditions to evaluate its potential for large-scale alkaline water electrolysis. Using the commercial RN electrode as the cathode and the NiFeOxHy-PN electrode or commercial RN electrode as the anode, the alkaline water electrolysis was carried out in 30% KOH at 85 °C. Owing to the presence of highly active NiFeOxHy nanosheets, NiFeOxHy-PN exhibits higher current density than commercial RN at the same cell voltage ( Fig. 7a). The porous structure of NiFeOxHy-PN favors the diffusion of gas bubbles and transport of electrolytes, leading to excellent water electrolysis performance especially at high current densities. To deliver a high current density of 400 mA cm−2, the NiFeOxHy-PN electrode only requires a cell voltage of 1.863 V, much lower than the commercial RN electrode (1.966 V) (Fig. 7b). To evaluate the durability of NiFeOxHy-PN under the industrial condition, the stability test was performed at 400 mA cm−2 for 12 h. Surprisingly, the NiFeOxHy-PN requires a lower cell voltage and exhibits higher stability than commercial RN (Fig. 7c). The degradation in the activity during the stability test is negligible performance degradation, indicating the potential of NiFeOxHy-PN for industrial application (Fig. 7d). In addition, the long-term stability test of NiFeOxHy-PN for 120 h under industrial conditions was performed to further confirm the durability (Fig. S8).

In summary, the efficient and durable NiFeOxHy-PN electrocatalyst was successfully fabricated through a facile two-step electrodeposition process, in which the highly active NiFeOxHy nanosheets were grown on the PN uniformly. Coupled ultrathin NiFeOxHy nanosheets with hierarchical PN substrate, the as-prepared NiFeOxHy-PN electrocatalyst provided more highly active sites as well as space for electrolyte diffusion and gas release. The optimized NiFeOxHy-PN electrocatalyst shows superior OER performance with an extremely low overpotential of 265 mV at 100 mA cm−2. When served as the anode for alkaline water electrolysis under industrial condition, the NiFeOxHy-PN deliver 400 mA cm−2 at the cell voltage of 1.86 V. In addition, the durability test was operated at 400 mA cm−2 for 120 h, the negligible performance degradation of NiFeOxHy-PN indicates its promising stability for industrial application. Owing to the facile scalable electrodeposition process, it is hopeful to develop low-cost highly active NiFeOxHy-PN electrocatalyst for alkaline water electrolysis.

Bo Zhong: led the experiments, wrote up the manuscript. Panyong Kuang: assisted in the experiments, wrote up part of the manuscript. Linxi Wang: revised the manuscript, supplied funding for the research. Jiaguo Yu: led the project, revised the manuscript, supplied funding for the research.
